loans.name: Ana María

texts.es: Ana María es socia del Bancomunal Fuerza, tiene 28 años de edad, tiene 2 hijos y es socia de FINCA Perú hace 3 años. Se dedica a la compra y venta por mayor de carne y cereales. Le gusta mucho asistir a las reuniones de su Bancomunal y le tiene mucha estima a su promotora. El préstamo que solicita lo invertirá en la compra de carne y cereales por mayor.
texts.en:
Ana María is a member of the Communal Bank "Fuerza" (Strength). She is 28 years old and has two children. Ana María has been with FINCA Peru for three years. She buys and sells meats and grains in bulk. She thoroughly enjoys attending the Communal Bank meetings and has a great amount of respect for her loan officer.

The loan she is requesting will be invested in the purchase of meats and grains in bulk.

loans.use: to buy meats and grains in bulk.

loans.name: Karen Jicell

texts.es: Karen tiene 27 años. Está casada con José quien es maestro constructor. Tienen dos hijos menores de edad. Es bachiller y nació en Colonche. Colonche es un poblado de pequeña extensión con amplia trayectoria en el trabajo de la madera, pues es la carpintería el oficio de gran parte de sus habitantes. Actualmente vive en La Libertad que pertenece a Guayaquil. Empezó su negocio por la necesidad de tener un ingreso adicional y como la venta se le da bien incursiono en la ropa. Gracias a esfuerzo y trabajo diario han salido adelante. Su horario de trabajo es de lunes a viernes en la mañana ya que aprovecha que sus hijos se encuentran en la escuela.  Su mayor preocupación como madre es que sus hijos se enfermen y no pueda realizar la venta. Con el crédito va a comprar zapatos, uniforme y ropa. En los próximos años desea construir su casa y tener un seguro familiar para proteger a sus seres queridos.
texts.en:
Karen, age 27, is married to José, a master builder.  They have two minor children.  She has a high school education, and she was born in Colonche.  Colonche is a settlement in a small area that works extensively with wood.  Carpentry is the trade of a large part of the population. 

She currently lives in La Libertad, which is in Guayaqul.  She started her business because she needed to have additional income.  As she is good at sales, she started selling clothes.  Thanks to her effort and daily work, they have gotten ahead.

Her work schedule is from Monday through Friday mornings, taking advantage of the fact that her children are in school.  Her biggest concern as a mother is that her children will get sick, and then she will not be able to sell.

She will use the loan to buy shoes, uniforms, and clothes.  In the coming years she wishes to build her house and to have her family be secure  in order to protect her loved ones.

loans.use: to buy shoes, uniforms, and clothes.

loans.name: Faraja Group

texts.en:
Stella, who is in her early 30s is married with three children; two of them go to school.  She has been a tailor since 2007.  She works from 7.00 am to 6.30 pm daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be her 8th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to increase her sewing equipment and has paid back all her loans successfully.  She wants a loan to buy materials for making more clothes to sell.  Her dream is to one day be able to own a cosmetics shop.

She will share this loan with her loan group "Faraja" which has a total of 17 members who will hold each accountable for paying back their loans.

loans.use: to buy materials for making more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Carmen Daniela

texts.es:
Carmen  es una mujer que tiene 19 años de edad, de estado civil soltera,   vive  en casa propia con sus padres. Se menciona que  La calidad de vida en la comunidad es de subsistencia, la mayoría de moradores  son trabajadores independientes  que se dedican al comercio y crianza de animales menores y algunos de ellos adicionalmente dedicados a la agricultura. Carmen  vive en  el  distrito de Las Lomas y departamento de  Piura, así mismo cuenta solamente con el servicio  básico de energía eléctrica, y el consumo de agua lo hacen a través de un pozo artezanal;  Así mismo todas las familias que radican ahí viven bajo estas condiciones.
 La actividad comercial a la que se dedica Carmen es la crianza/venta de ganado porcinos  y aves de corral, la crianza de estos animales la realiza en corrales externos a  su domicilio; cabe destacar que en esta actividad Carmen cuenta con 2 años de experiencia, lo que le ha permitido mantener su clientela ya establecida en este negocio; ella vende sus animales a los comerciantes mayoristas de la zona; Así mismo sus padres le apoyan en esta actividad.
Actualmente Carmen se ha propuesto ampliar su inventario en lo referente a su crianza y venta de animales, esto debido a que es una actividad muy rentable en la zona; es por estas circunstancias  que esta solicitando un nuevo préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa por un monto de S/.1500 nuevos soles el cual estará destinado a la inversión de compra de alimentos balanceados, y arreglos de corrales para sus animales; lo cual en el tiempo le va permitir ir mejorando su nivel de VIDA.
texts.en:
Carmen is a 19 year old woman, single, living at home with her parents. The quality of life is subsistence level. Most of the residents are self-employed working in trade and breeding small animals and also some of them work in agriculture. Carmen lives in the district of Las Lomas and in the department of Piura, with only the basic service of electricity and they obtain their water through an artesian well, and all the families who settle here live under these conditions.

Carmen’s commercial activity is breeding and selling cattle, pigs, and poultry. She raises these animals in pens outside her home. It is noteworthy that Carmen has two years of experience in this business. She sells her animals to the wholesalers in the area, and her parents support her in this activity.

Currently Carmen has proposed expanding her inventory of breeding and selling animals because this activity is very profitable in her area, and because of these circumstances she is requesting a new loan from Edpyme Aternative in the amount of 1500 soles which will be earmarked for the investment of buying animal feed and making repairs to the animal pens, which in time will allow her to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy animal feed and to repair the animal pens

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
Jacqueline is 30 years old and is married with two children. She also takes care of one dependent. She sells various goods such as: potatoes, rice, sorghum, etc. and she has been in this business for 2 years. Her business is open from 7 a.m to 6 p.m every day of the week and she currently employs two people to help her. 

Jacqueline has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase various goods such as: potatoes, rice, and sorghum in sacks, etc. to sell. With any profits, she will be able to save for her future and she will be able to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase various goods such as: potatoes, rice, sorghum in sacks, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Valeri

texts.en:
Valeri is 44 years old. He lives with his sister and 15-year old-nephew, who studies in the local school. The family runs an agricultural business. Valeri has milking cows; he produces cheese and sells it on the local open market. The total average monthly income of the family is 800 Laris. They work hard but still live in poverty.

Valeri requested a loan for purchasing calves. He wants to grow them and sell them after a few months with a price mark-up. Valeri keeps livestock in good conditions and takes good care of them. Thus, he wants to expand his business in order to make the desired profit. 

With the increased amount, he will be able to repair the cattle-shed because the existing one is small and old. In a new building, he will be able to keep more calves and sell more products. Along with the above mentioned, the living conditions of the family will be improved.

Valeri relies on your help and mercy.

loans.use: to purchase calves.

loans.name: Elijah

texts.en:
Elijah is 28 years old. He is married to Mary and together they have two children. He is a farmer and has been in the business for the past one year.

This is his first loan from KADET LTD, after he was introduced by one of our field officers. He will use the loan to purchase fertilizer and seedlings for planting.

He hopes to expand his business and manage to see his children through their education.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Millicent

texts.en:
Millicent is a single mother of 2 children, both of whom attend school. They live in their own house which has electricity but no piped water. Millicent has a business renting houses, which she has been operating for the past 5 years. This is their major source of income, and their biggest monthly expenditures are food and school fees. 

The greatest challenge facing Millicent's business is repairs, which sometimes use up a lot of money. Her goal is to own many houses. Millicent wants to use the loan to renovate her properties.

loans.use: to renovate her houses

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine is 36 years old and is married with five children. She sells drugs for animals and she has been in this business for one year. Her business is open from 7 a.m to 6 p.m every day. 

Justine has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more drugs for animals to resell. With any profits, she will be able to save for her future and she will be able to re-invest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase more drugs for animals for resale

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en: Rehema is married with 5 children, all of whom attend school. They live in a rented house without electricity or water. Rehema has her own business selling palm wine, which she has been selling for the past 10 years. She works from home and sells to passersby and people living in the surrounding community. Her biggest challenges are seasonality and rises in prices. Rehema joined Yehu because of their effieciency with loans. In the future, Rehema wants to keep growing her business and eventually start a new one. Rehema will use the loan to buy a jerry can of palm wine.

loans.use: To buy a jerry can of palm wine

loans.name: Wangechi

texts.en:
Wangechi is married with one child, who is still a toddler so not yet attending school. They live in a rented house that has electricity but no piped water and the biggest family expense is food. 

Wangechi has a business selling fruit and vegetables. She sells the products in the open air to passersby. The biggest challenge affecting the business is seasonality. Wangechi would like to use the loan to build a "kibanda" that would protect her business from this year's rainy season. She would also like to construct shelves to create more space for stock. Wangechi's goals for the future are to keep expanding this business and eventually to start a new one.

loans.use: To construct a "kibanda" (shelter) to protect her stall from the rain

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is 39 years old. She is from Ndunyu Njeru and is married to Peter. They have five children who are all in school.

Nancy is a farmer. She has applied for her third loan from KADET LTD to enable her to pay school fees for her child. She is happy that she can apply for this kind of loan to help educate her children. 

She hopes to become the best farmer in her area.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her child.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is 34 years old. He is married to Mary and together they have six school-going children. He is a cobbler and has been in the business for the past 12 years.

This is his first term loan from KADET LTD. He will use the loan amount to purchase shoe-making materials such as leather sheets, soles, inner soles, shoelaces and shoe polishes for use in his business.

He hopes to own a large shoe-making company in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase leather sheets, soles, inner soles, shoelaces and shoe polishes for use in his business.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 39 years old and a single mother of two children aged 14 and 17 years old. She has a clothes selling business in Nakuru town and has been in the business for the past six years. Apart from clothes, she also sells curtains and bedding such as pillows, bed covers and bed sheets.

This will be her first loan from KADET LTD, and she plans to use the amount to buy more stock of clothes and bedding to sell in her business and satisfy her customers' needs and demands.

In the future, Elizabeth hopes to invest more in her business and make more income as well as provide good living standards for her family.

loans.use: To buy more stock of clothes.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Thank you for the support you have shown to Halima and her business. The last loan improved Halima's stock taking rate. Since the previous loan, she has had additional income to augment the normal one. 

Her goal is to be able to fund her children's education through her business. 

Halima wants the new loan to expand her existing business and purchase stock.

loans.use: To purchase stock for the business.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is married and has two children, both of whom attend school. They live in their own house that has electricity but no water. Her husband is a businessman and their greatest monthly expenditures are school fees and food. 

Mary operates her own poultry business that she has been running for nearly 10 years now. She works from home and she gets orders from hotels and cafes as well as from neighbors and passersby. The biggest problem facing her business is chicken disease and the ever-increasing prices of chicken feed. 

Mary would like to use the money from the loan to buy feeds, vaccines and sawdust. Mary decided to work with Yehu because of the low rates of interest.

loans.use: to buy feeds, vaccines and saw dust.

loans.name: Kakhaber

texts.en:
Kakhaber is 32 years old. He lives in a small village in Ozurgeti District with his family, which consists of his wife Miranda, an 11-year-old daughter, a 9 year-old son and his parents. Kakhaber's children attend school. All adult family members are involved in the family agricultural business. Kakhaber has 2 tractors, which are used for agricultural works mainly in citrus gardens. Kakhaber provides agricultural services to neighboring farmers and is paid for these services. He also rents out another tractor. In addition, the family owns 2 milk cows. Miranda produces cheese and sells it at the local open market to dairy products retailers. Kakhaber’s parents are mainly busy with a family-owned citrus garden on 1.2 hectares of land. The citrus is sold to local citrus processing companies. The total average monthly income of the family is 800 Laris.

Kakhaber has requested credit to buy parasite treatments for the citrus trees. Properly done seasonal works are the prerequisites of a good harvest in the fall. Kakhaber and his family will work hard during the year to get a quality harvest and sell it for a good price. The family will receive a profit  that will be used for financing family needs and improving their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase parasite treatments for the plants

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is 46 years old. He is married to Ann and together they have three school-going children. 

He is a carpenter and has been in the business for the past four years.

This is his first loan from KADET Ltd. He was introduced by one of our field officers. He will use the loan to purchase timber and nails for use in his business.

He hopes to be a well known carpenter in his area.

loans.use: to purchase timber and nails for use in his business.

loans.name: Zablon

texts.en:
Zablon used his first loan to buy two dairy cows for rearing. He plans to use this loan to buy dairy meal and hay grass for his dairy cattle. This will enable him to get more dairy milk for sale and thereby meet his clients' demands.

In the future, Zablon hopes to expand his dairy farming by supplying milk in the whole of Olkalau town, hence becoming one of the leading dairy farmers in the area.

loans.use: To buy dairy meal and hay.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a married mother of two children, both of whom attend school. They live in their own house, which has access to electricity but not to piped water. Sarah's greatest monthly expense is food. 

Sarah has a poultry business that she has been running for eight years now. The biggest challenges facing her business are transport and water. Her goal for the future is to keep on expanding her business. 

Sarah would like to use the loan to fit her house with running water.

loans.use: To bring water to the house.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Thank you for the support you have shown to Margaret and her business. 

Margaret would like to take out a new loan. To keep on expanding her business, she would purchase different varieties of cereals. 

The last loan helped Margaret as it increased her stock, and the added income helped to sustain her family. In the future she would like to start a new business.

loans.use: To purchase different varieties of cereals.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua is a food vendor. She sells maize porridge. She serves it with milk and bread to her customers. She is married and has four children. She has been in this business for five years now. She uses her income to help her husband to feed and clothe their children and pay their school fees. Her loan will be used to purchase bags of maize and flour to prepare porridge and bread to sell. With the new profit, Efua will expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase bags of maize and flour to prepare porridge and bread to sell.

loans.name: María

texts.es:
María tiene 27 años, es una mujer soltera y sin hijos. Vive en la casa de sus tíos, ubicada en el distrito de San Ramón – Chanchamayo.

Ella se dedica a la venta de carne de aves en un puesto de ventas que tiene en el mercado de su localidad. Sus tíos, con lo que vive, fueron quienes la impulsaron a realizar este negocio y ya lleva casi 3 años en con ello. Gracias a este trabajo puede comprarse lo necesario y darse algunos gustos. María es responsable con su trabajo, pues cada madrugada visita a sus proveedores y adquiere los pollos más tiernos, de esta manera sus clientes están satisfechos con la calidad de carne que ofrece.
Su horario de trabajo es de las 5 de la mañana hasta la 1 de la tarde, luego se vuelve a abastecer, y cuando tiene tiempo disponible ayuda en las labores de la casa.
María tiene como meta abrir una carnicería más completa, donde ofrezca diversas carnes, porque sabe del negocio y lo considera rentable.

Ésta es la primera vez que accede a un crédito con MFP, por eso da su palabra de ser puntual en el pago de las cuotas. Pertenece al banco comunal “Mujeres Trabajadoras”, cuyas integrantes son mujeres con los mismos deseos de superación.
Invertirá el dinero que solicita en la compra de pollos y gallinas para la venta de la carne en su puesto.
texts.en:
Maria is 27 years old.  She is a single woman without children.  She lives in her uncle and aunt's house in the district of San Ramon, Chanchamayo.

She works selling bird meat in a stall that she has in her town's market.  Her aunt and uncle, with whom she lives, were the ones who urged her to start this business and now she has been doing it for almost three years.  Thanks to this work she can buy herself what she needs and give herself a few pleasures.

Maria is responsible with her work.  Every morning at dawn she visits her wholesalers and gets the tenderest chickens.  In this way her clients are satisfied with the quality of meat that she offers.  Her work hours are from 5 in the morning until 1 in the afternoon.  Later she returns to resupply and when she has free time she helps with the housework.

Maria's goal is to open a more complete butcher shop where she can offer a variety of meats, because she knows about this business and thinks it can be successful.

This is the first time that she is getting a loan from MFP, and because of this she gives her word to be punctual in making her payments.  She belongs to the communal bank Mujeres Trabajadoras (Hardworking Women), whose members are women with the same desire to succeed.  She will invest the money that she is requesting in the purchase of chickens and hens to sell the meat in her stall.

loans.use: to increase her merchandise.

loans.name: Nana

texts.en:
Nana is 43 years old. She lives in a small village in the Kobuleti district, at the seaside of Georgia. She is married and lives with her husband, Emzar, and her four children (22, 20, 15 and 11 years old). The two younger children go to school. The elder children help their parents in the family agricultural business. 

They have 2 hectares of land where they grow fruits and vegetables. Nana and Emzar sell the harvested products at the local open market. Also the family has two milk cows. Nana sells milk at the same market. The total average monthly income of the family is 1,000 GEL. 

Nana requested credit for purchasing saplings of nuts. She will plant them in the family yard and after two years, the family will get the first harvest. Nana will sell the nuts locally to nut exporters. The income of the family will increase in the long term. 

Nana plans to constantly reinvest the profit in the family business to expand it in the future.

loans.use: to purchase saplings of nuts for planting.

loans.name: Patiance

texts.en:
Patiance is a single mother of two children, both of whom are attending school. They live in their own home that has electricity but no running water. Her greatest expenses are school fees and food.

She operates a poultry business from home, which she has been running for the last three years now. The business is their major source of income. She gets orders from hotels, cafes, neighbors and friends. The biggest problem facing the business is threat of epidemics that may cause loss of livestock.

Her business aspiration is to own a big poultry farm. Patiance joined Yehu because of their affordability. She will use the loan to install water at home, both for her business and for domestic use.

loans.use: To install water at home for business and domestic use.

loans.name: Ayudanos Señor 2, 3 & 7 Group

texts.en:
Cleotilde is the coordinator of her group, Ayudanos Senor (Help Us, Lord) 2, 3 & 7, a group made up of mostly Haitian citizens. They are located in the city of La Romana, where decades ago Haitians emigrated to work in the sugarcane industry. They all live in a rural community outside of the main city. Their community is a "batey," where most of the people live without services and where it is necessary to go to a closer city to get everything they want.

Cleotilde and her long-term partner make their home here in a simple structure with their three children. She is excited to be taking her 4th loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She has been running her business for almost four years. She started investing in calling cards when many people bought prepaid cellphones because they need to buy calling cards to recharge their mobile credits.  Over time she started buying clothes to sell. Now she is investing this loan to buy more products like cosmetics and shoes, while continuing buying clothes. This new loan will give her the opportunity to increase her sales and to have access to more clients.

She will use this loan to purchase clothing, shoes, and miscellaneous products. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To pay for clothes, shoes, cosmetics and other miscellaneous products to sell

loans.name: Cristo Salva 6 & 7 Group

texts.en:
Yolena, the coordinator of the Cristo Salva Groups (Christ save) 6 & 7, is a Haitian mother like the other 9 hard-working women in the group. This group is composed of 10 Haitian immigrants located in the city of La Romana, where tourists and sugarcane are the biggest industries. They all live in a rural area called a "batey," surrounded by sugarcane fields. 

Yolena's family is made up of two children and her long-term partner. Her children are attending school, which has been her most difficult challenge because they are Haitian and they didn't know how to speak Spanish very well. She wants to have her house and a stable business, to save and live a tranquil and safe life.

Yolena is very excited to receive her third loan through Esperanza International. She took her first loan around a year ago. Receiving these loans has made it possible to invest in her small business. She produces candy with traditional preparations. She makes candies from peanuts, coconut and milk. She sells them door-to-door by walking in the streets. She will invest by purchasing milk, sugar, coconut, peanuts, cinnamon, etc.

One of Yolena's dreams is to have a beautiful house and a successful business. She thanks you all for your support!!

loans.use: To pay for milk, sugar, coconut, peanuts, cinnamon, and other ingredients for preparing candies

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en: Adjoa is married and has four children. Adjoa makes Fanti kenkey [fermented corn dough wrapped in corn or banana leaves] for sale. She has done this for three years. She uses her income to help her husband feed and clothe their children and pay their school fees. Adjoa will use her loan to purchase bags of maize, leaves and firewood to produce her kenkey for sale. With the new profit, she will expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase bags of maize, leaves and firewood to produce her kenkey for sale

loans.name: Judith Candida

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal Nuevos Horizontes se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Jipijapa, cantón conocido con el nombre de la sultana del café por los extensos cultivos de café el cual tiene un sabor incomparable, por su gastronomía y por la calidez de su gente. 

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Judith, tiene 36 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen tres hijos de 19, 15 y 8 años de edad, todos ellos estudian en universidad, colegio y escuela. Su esposo es maestro constructor.

Ella  es una muy buena ama de casa que además tiene a cargo el bar en una escuela de la localidad, muy de mañana se levanta a preparar sus bocadillos como: empanadillas, corviches, sanduches, otros alimentos y jugos naturales, para luego llevar al bar de la escuela y venderles a los alumnos que asisten a este centro de estudios, ella también en las tardes y fines de semana vende ropa por catalogo. Trabaja todos los días en el bar de lunes  a viernes y con sus ventas de ropa los fines de semana, ella lleva 12 años con su negocio y le va muy bien.

Este crédito lo va utilizar en comprar aceite, plátanos, maní, víveres para la preparación de los alimentos y también ropa para la venta.  Lleva 11 años en el Banco Comunal y le gusta por la ayuda que les da la institución con los créditos.
 
Su sueño es darles lo mejor a sus hijos.
texts.en:
The New Horizons Communal Bank gets together twice a month in the Canton of Jipijapa. This canton is known for the name of the Sultana Coffee because of the extensive cultivation of coffee which has an incomparable flavor, for its gastronomy and the warmth of its people.

This is where we meet Judith, who is 36 years old, married and they have three children who are 19, 15 and 8 years old. All of them are school students or at university. Her husband is a master builder.

She is a very good housewife who also manages a food bar at a local school, getting up very early to prepare her snacks such as meat pies, corviches [green banana dough with fish or shrimp, fried in a small patty], sandwiches, and other food and natural juices so that later when she arrives at the school food bar she can sell them to the students attending classes there. Also, in the afternoons and weekends she sells clothing by catalog. She works daily in the food bar from Monday through Friday and selling clothing on the weekends. She has been in this business for 12 years and it is going very well.

She is going to use the money from the loan to buy oil, bananas, peanuts, and groceries in order to prepare her dishes, and also clothing to sell. She has been doing business with the communal bank for 11 years and she likes it because of the support that the institution gives her with the loans. 

Her dream is to provide the best for her children.

loans.use: to buy oil, bananas, peanuts, food supplies, and clothing

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John, 59, has operated a retail business in Olkalou town for the last two years. He is married to Mary, who is a farmer, and together they have four children.

He was introduced to KADET Ltd. by one of the existing clients and this will be his first loan from KADET. He plans to use this loan to buy more stock of sugar, tea leaves, cooking fat and baking flour.

In the future, John hopes to grow his business and make more income and, thereafter, buy a plot of land and build rental houses.

loans.use: To buy more stock of sugar, tea leaves, cooking fat and baking flour.

loans.name: Zurab

texts.en:
Zurab is 40 years old. He lives in a small village in the Khelvachauri district, West Georgia. Zurab is married and lives with his wife, Makvala, and two sons (17 and 12 years old). Both of them go to school. 

Zurab is a worker in the village. Also, he is actively involved in the family agricultural business. They have 1 hectare of land where they grow fruits and vegetables. Zurab sells harvested products to greengrocery retailers at the local open market. The total average monthly income of the family is 900 GEL.

Zurab requested credit to start a small trade business. He will purchase seasonal greengrocery products from farmers at wholesale prices and sell them in nearby towns from his car. According to Credo and Zurab’s estimations, the business will be profitable. The family will get additional profit and will be able to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase fruits & vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Araba

texts.en: Araba is a food vendor. She cooks banku [a local dish made from corn dough] for sale. She serves it with okro and fish stew. She has done this for three years. She is married and has three children. She lives with her husband in Essiam near Abura. Her husband is a trader. She uses her income to help her husband pay for their children’s school fees. Her loan will be used to purchase bags of maize and fish which she uses in preparing her banku for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to create a place for her customers to eat.

loans.use: to purchase bags of maize and fish which she uses in preparing her banku for sale

loans.name: Las Responsables 1, 2 & 4 Group

texts.en:
Celia is one of the members of the group Las Responsables (The Responsible) 1, 2 & 4. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her 4 children and their father. She is a hard-working woman and helps her family by bringing in extra income.

Celia is excited to be taking her 6th loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and growing her business. She has had her business for 8 and a half years, starting with her own savings after working in different jobs. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by purchasing shoes. She sells her product by walking and from her home.

She will use the profits to reinvest in her business and providing for her family needs.  She is helping her long-term partner by bringing extra income. This group is located in one of the "bateyes" near La Romana, and its members are mostly Haitians. Bateyes are rural areas surrounded by sugarcane fields.

loans.use: To buy shoes

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi produces charcoal for sale at  Essiam, which she has done for 2 years now.  Esi is a single parent and has 4 children.  She uses her income to feed her children and to pay their school fees.  Esi will use her loan to purchase firewood to produce the charcoal to sell.  With the new profit from her expanded business, Esi will produce the charcoal in large quantities.

loans.use: to purchase firewood to produce the charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi sells charcoal at Essiam, which she has done for 2 years now. Esi is a single parent and has 4 children.  She uses her income to feed her children and to pay their school fees.  Esi will use her loan to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell.  With the new profit from her expanded business, Esi would like to produce the charcoal she sells.

loans.use: to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Araba

texts.en: Araba  is a baker.  She bakes cake and bread  for sale, which she has done for some years now.  She is married with one child.  Araba uses her income to support her husband in the general upkeep of their home.  Araba will use her loan to purchase flour, sugar and cooking oil for her bakery. With the new profit, she will buy a modern type of oven to make her work easier.

loans.use: to purchase flour, sugar and cooking oil for her bakery

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua sells waakye (rice and beans cooked together). She serves it with gari, macaroni, meat and fish stew.  Efua has been selling waakye for several  years now.  She is married, and her husband is a mason.  She uses her income to support her husband in paying the family's utility bills.  Efua needs this loan to purchase bags of rice, beans and other ingredients for the preparation of her waakye for sale. With the new profit, Efua will expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase bags of rice, beans and other ingredients for the preparation of her waakye for sale

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena extracts oil from palm kernels and sells it at Essiam near Wireduwa, which she has done for 20 years.  Abena is  married with 4 children;  her husband is a farmer.  She uses her income to support her husband in feeding and clothing their children.  Abena will use her loan to purchase more palm kernels to extract oil for sale. With the new profit, she wishes to buy a machine to extract the palm oil.

loans.use: to purchase more palm kernels to extract oil for sale

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba is married and has 4 children.  Aba produces Fanti kenkey (fermented corn dough wrapped in leaves) for sale.  In front of Aba is the kenkey she has   produced.  She has been in this business for 6 years.  Aba uses her income to support her husband in feeding and clothing their children, as well as paying for school fees.  Aba will use her loan to purchase bags of maize, leaves and firewood to produce her kenkey for sale. With the new profit, she will expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase bags of maize, leaves and firewood to produce kenkey for sale

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua extracts palm oil for sale at Essiam near Abura. Ekua is a single parent and has 6 children. As a single parent, she uses her income to feed and clothe her children. Ekua will use her loan to purchase more palm fruit to extract oil for sale. With the new profit, she wishes to buy a machine for her business.

loans.use: to purchase more palm fruit to extract oil for sale

loans.name: Las Responsables 5 & 6 Group

texts.en:
Maribel is the coordinator of her group, Las Responsables (The Responsible) 5 & 6. All these members are mainly Haitians. This group is located in one of the Bateyes from La Romana. Bateyes are rural areas surrounded by sugarcane fields. Maribel makes her home here in a simple structure with her four children and her long time partner. In the meantime, she plans to continue enjoying to work and take care of her children.

Maribel is excited to be taking her first loan with Esperanza. She has had her business for around a year. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by purchasing fruits, vegetables, charcoal, chicken, and other goods. She runs a Fruits and Vegetables stall. She will use the profits to reinvest in her business. She is very motivated to invest in her business and she hope this first loan will one step to develop her business and to change the lives of her family.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama is a fruit vendor. She sells oranges. She lives together with her husband and five children in Essiam near Abura. She uses her income to help her husband with the general upkeep of their family. Ama will use her loan to purchase a variety of fruit to sell. With the new profit, she will expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of fruit to sell

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua is a single parent and has 5 children. She sells vegetables such as tomatoes, eggplant, and onions at Essiam near Abura. As a single parent, she uses her income to feed and clothe her children and to pay their school fees. Ekua will use her loan to purchase a variety of vegetables to sell. With the new profit she will expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama is a petty trader. She sell saucepans and cooking utensils, a business that she has had for three years now. 

Ama is a single parent and has five children. She uses her income to pay her childrens' school fees. She will use her loan to purchase saucepans and cooking utensils to sell. With the new profit she will expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase saucepans and cooking utensils to sell.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a resident of Malindi, Kenya. He is a retailer, having run a retail shop for three years. He started the business from a loan he received from another financial institution.

John learned of Milango from his friends and is applying for a loan of 15,900 Kenya shillings (KES) to purchase items such as paraffin and cereals. He aspires to open up other retail stores in the future. The additional income from the loan will help John pay for his childrens' education despite the challenge of price fluctuations.

loans.use: To purchase items such as paraffin and cereals.

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en:
Mwanasha is a 52-year-old divorced woman with seven children, of whom one is enrolled in school. She lives in her own house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and medical bills for her family.

Mwanasha has operated a cafe for the past 6 years, selling food to the general public. She faces a major challenge of seasonality. She aspires to own a bigger restaurant.

With this loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings (KES), she wants to purchase additional stock of wheat flour, maize flour, and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access funds to boost her business.

loans.use: To buy additional stock of wheat flour, maize flour, and cooking oil for her business.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a resident of Kitale in Western Kenya and is a father of four children between 4 and 18 years old, all of whom are schooling. He has been in farming for 10 years and currently has one farmhand employed in his farm. He produces mainly maize and milk, which are both sold within the local market.

John has requested a loan of 100,000 Kenya shillings (KES) from Juhudi Kilimo, which he will use to buy poultry birds at 50,000 KES and also build a modern dairy unit at 50,000 KES. He says the venture into poultry will boost his farming income and help him expand his farming acreage, besides meeting his family's basic needs.

He points at poor roads transport and market prices as the major challenges. However, he appreciates Juhudi Kilimo's efficiency in providing loans.

loans.use: To buy poultry birds and build a poultry unit.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa is a resident of Kisii, in Kenya, and has been in farming for 6 successive years with her farm producing mainly beans, maize, and nappier grass for the local market. She is 47 and married with six children, three of whom are still schooling. She also runs a cereal retail shop in the local market.
  
Teresa has requested a loan of 90,000 Kenya shillings (KES) from Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to help her buy a dairy cow at 80,000 KES as well as renovate her dairy unit at a cost of 10,000 KES. She says the milk produced will be sold to meet other family needs besides supplementing the family's daily meals.

Her main farming challenges include mainly poor market prices for farm produce, as well as occasional droughts and pests that destroy farm produce.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow and renovate her dairy unit.

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana is a teacher, a farmer, and a mother of five children who are between 20 and 27 years old, with the last one still undergoing college education.

Juliana has been in farming for 10 years and currently employs two farmhands. Her farm produces mainly maize that is sold to the local market and nappier grass that she sells to the local dairy farmers.

Juliana says she will use the loan to buy a dairy cow and boost her dairy farming business. The milk she adds will supplement her family's meals and ensure the education of her last-born child. She hopes to own five dairy cows in 5 years.

She laments unpredictable weather conditions, pests, and diseases.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Sibiah

texts.en:
Sibiah is a resident and farmer in Kisii, Kenya. She has 30 years of experience in farming. Her farm is managed with the help of three farmhands currently. Her produce consists mainly of maize, beans and napier grass, which is sold at the local market. She runs a milling machines business for additional income. She laments of the effect of pests and diseases which often destroy farm produce before harvest.

Sibiah has requested a loan of 80,000 Kenyan shillings from Juhudi Kilimo to help her buy a dairy cow. This is her second loan request with Juhudi Kilimo and she hopes to earn better income and expand her farm by buying more land in five years’ time.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Isabella

texts.en:
Isabella is a mother of six children aged between twenty two years and twenty years. She has been in active farming for ten years and sells her produce of maize and beans to the local market. Her farm is currently run with the help of one farmhand engaged on permanent basis. She has also started a private school in her local area.
Isabella has requested a loan of 62,400 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. She hopes to grow the dairy business and improve the quality of her dairy cows as she focuses on expanding her school as well. She is optimistic her family will get enough milk for consumption too.
She too mentions pests and diseases as the major challenges coupled with occasional droughts.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Meshee

texts.en:
Meshee is a married woman with three children, of whom one is enrolled in school. Her husband, who is a farmer, also contributes to the provision of the family's basic needs. She lives in her own house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family.

Meshee has operated a fish selling business for the past 10 years; she sells partly from her shop and partly door-to-door to her neighbors and friends. She faces a major challenge of seasonality. She aspires to open a kiosk in the future.

With this loan of 30,000 Kenya shillings (KES), she wants to purchase more stock of fish. She decided to join Yehu to access funds to boost her business.

loans.use: To buy additional stock of fish.

loans.name: Siwatu

texts.en:
Siwatu is a married woman with no children. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food. 

For the past two years, she has operated a green grocery business, selling mostly vegetables to her customers at the market. She faces a major challenge of seasonality; during the rainy season, it becomes very difficult to transport her goods from and to the market. She dreams of starting a kiosk in another location.

With this loan of 10,000 Kenya shillings (KES), she wants to purchase additional stock of potatoes and tomatoes for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to uplift her living standards.

loans.use: To purchase addtional stock of potatoes, tomatoes, and cabbages.

loans.name: Alexina

texts.en:
Alexina is 63 years old and has 20 solid years in mixed farming. Her farm currently produces napier grass and maize, which she sells to the local market. She runs her farm with the help of two farmhands.

Alexina has made a loan request with Juhudi Kilimo amounting to 80,000 Kenya shillings (KES), which she will use to buy a dairy cow for a venture into dairy farming. She says the milk produce will supplement her family's daily meals and enable her to make savings in order to invest in better breeds of dairy cows in the future.

She laments of low market prices for farm produce and occasional drought. She is grateful to Juhudi Kilimo for the first loan she had acquired and the support to small farmers.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Tima

texts.en:
Tima is a 24-year-old married woman with three children who are enrolled in school. Her husband, who is employed, also contributes to the provision of the family’s basic needs. She lives in her own house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for her family and school fees.

Tima has operated a food stall business for the past three years; she sells mainly flat bread and sweetbread to her neighbors and friends. She faces a major challenge of seasonality. She aspires to own a well-stocked cereals shop.

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase more stock of wheat flour, cooking fat, and baking flour. She decided to join Yehu to access funds to boost her business.

loans.use: to buy wheat flour, baking powder, and cooking oil for her food business.

loans.name: Alexander

texts.en:
Alexander is a father of four children between the ages of 12 and 3 years old. He lives with his family in their rural home in the Kisii area of Kenya where he has practiced mixed farming for ten years. Farming is his sole source of income.

Alexander has requested a loan of 62,400 Kenyan shillings from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. He is focusing on using his farming income to educate his children, three of whom are already in school. He also hopes to run a transport business in the future to help supply his produce to the market. He says the poor state of the roads remains a challenge, as farmers are compelled to supply local markets which have very low prices for farm produce.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en:
Jackson is a resident of Kitale and the father of one child, aged three years. He runs a retail shop in the local market and has been in active farming for six consecutive years within his rural home area. His farm produce, which includes maize, milk, and beans, are sold within the local market.

Jackson has requested a first loan of 62,400 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. This, he says, will boost his farming income from the sale of milk and provide the family with milk for daily consumption.

He remains grateful to Juhudi Kilimo for the loan service to farmers. He points at unreliable rain patterns, high costs of inputs, and diseases as the major farming challenges.

loans.use: to buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a 24-year-old married woman with one child who is still too young for school. Her husband, who is employed, also contributes to the provision of the family's basic needs. They live in their own house with electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family.

Asha has operated a green grocery business for the past 2 years; she sells mainly vegetables. She faces a major challenge of high costs of transporting the goods from the source to her home, where she sells them to her neighbors and friends. She aspires to own a fish shop.

With this loan of 30,000 Kenya shillings (KES), she wants to purchase more stock of vegetables like tomatoes, kale, and cabbages. She decided to join Yehu to access funds to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase addtional stock of vegetables like tomatoes, kale, and cabbages.

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac is a resident of Kitale and has three children aged between ten and five years. He has been in farming for five years and sells his produce to the local market. His farm currently produces milk, maize, and beans.

Isaac has requested a loan of 60,000 KES from Juhidi Kilimo. This is his fifth loan request with Juhudi Kilimo. He reiterates that the loans have changed his family tremendously with the provision of basic needs and the education of the children. He says he will use the loan to venture into poultry farming, which will help in earning income in and out of season.

He sees undeveloped markets, theft of farm produce before harvesting, and diseases as the most worrying challenges.

loans.use: to buy poultry birds.

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha is a 32-year-old married woman with four children, two of whom are enrolled in school. Her husband is employed and also contributes to the provision of the family's basic needs. Mwanaisha lives in her own house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and medical bills for the family.

Mwanaisha has operated a kiosk for the past six years. She sells from her shop to her neighbors and friends. She faces the major challenge of high market competition. She aspires to own a well stocked wholesale. With this 30,000 Kenyan shilling loan, she wants to purchase more stock of wheat flour, sugar, rice and maize flour for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access funds to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock of wheat flour, rice and sugar for her kiosk

loans.name: Lucrecia

texts.en:
Lucrecia is a 44-year-old married woman with two children. She is a farmer from Talibon, Bohol. She primarily grows rice crops to sell. Lucrecia also sells banana cue and rice cakes in her community. She works hard to support her family and send her children to school.

Lucrecia has requested a loan to purchase fertilizers and food ingredients. She hopes for her ventures and children to succeed.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and food ingredients

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en:
Anecita is a married woman with 3 children. She lives in the town of Talibon, Bohol, with her family. To earn a living, Anecita makes dresses, uniforms, and curtains. She also provides general alterations to clothing. She earns 5000 PHP per month from her business. Anecita works hard to help provide for her household’s needs.

Anecita would like to request a loan to purchase cloth, needles, threads, and other materials. She hopes to grow her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth, needles, threads, and other materials

loans.name: Fuad

texts.en:
Fuad is 38 years old. He lives with his seven children in Ibb, Yemen. He runs a grocery store. He started his business by taking several loans from AMB in order to expand his business. He used these loans to open his store in a strategic area. Demand has increased because his customers are finding everything they need – high quality products, accessible prices and very good service. He is always very friendly. 

Fuad is requesting a loan of 400,000 Yemeni rials from AMB to buy rice, fruit, soft drinks, canned food and other items. His dream is to own a house instead of the leased house where he lives with his family. He hopes to expand his business to be a wholesaler.

loans.use: to buy rice, fruit, soft drinks and canned food

loans.name: Bonifacia

texts.en: Bonifacia is a 65-year-old married woman from Talibon, Bohol. She is involved in rice farming. Bonifacia works hard to provide for herself and her family. She requested a loan to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies. Bonifacia hopes to own a bigger farm. She also hopes for her family to have a more stable income.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Lydwina

texts.en:
Lydwina is 45-year-old  married woman with seven children. She and her husband run a fishing business. Her husband is a fisherman, and  he is the one who catches the fish. Lydwina sells her husband's catch at their town's market. She also sells dried fish to her neighborhood.

Lydwina is requesting a loan to purchase fishing nets and a fishing boat. She hopes to buy more fishing boats in the future. She also hopes to be able to send all her children to school.

loans.use: to purchase fishing nets and a fishing boat

loans.name: Ma. Magdalina

texts.en:
Ma. Magdalina runs a sari-sari (variety) store business in San Jose, Talibon. She sells various items like snacks, candies, cooking oil, and vinegar. She earns 5,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) per month with her business.

Ma. Magdalina's income is used for her family's daily needs. She needs additional capital for her business and sought the help of CEVI, an MFI and Kiva partner. She applied for a loan to buy more merchandise to sell, such as canned goods and toiletries. Magdalina hopes for her sales to improve.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise to sell, such as canned goods and toiletries.

loans.name: Huong

texts.en:
Huong, who is 55 years old, is married and has two children, a son and a daughter. She and her husband support their family through the income they earn from running a general store in front of their house. They have run this business for 6 years. They live in Ho Chi Minh City. 

Huong intends to use this loan to buy a larger quantity of basic products, such as foods and beverages, in bulk to sell at her store. The additional products will enable her to increase her sales and her income. She hopes her business runs smoothly and will help her to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to buy a larger quantity of products in bulk to sell at her store.

loans.name: Faisl

texts.en: Faisl is a 44-year-old man. He is married and has two children. They live in Sana'a, Yemen. He runs a clothing store. His dad helped him to open his business. This business helps him greatly, and he still has the opportunity to attract more customers. He is requesting a youth loan of 100,000 Yemeni rials from AMB which he will invest in his business. Specifically, he will buy garments like shirts, pants, shoes and other items, since he has orders to fill. In this way, he will increase his income and ultimately have better living conditions in his area.

loans.use: to buy garments like shirts, pants, shoes and other items for his business

loans.name: Van

texts.en:
Van is 35 years old and married with a son. She lives with her family in a small house in Ho Chi Minh City. Her husband earns income as a taxi driver. She has been running a food stall to earn a living. She sells noodles, soups, snack foods, and soft drinks to people in her community.

Van started her business 4 years ago. She intends to take a loan to expand her business by buying a variety of different beverages and better food to sell to her customers. 

She hopes her business runs smoothly and will help her to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To buy a variety of different beverages and better food to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Lang

texts.en:
Lang, 61, is married and has two children. She lives with her family in Ho Chi Minh city. To earn a living, she and her husband have been running a general store in which they sell household items and personal-use products for people in their community. They started this business six years ago. 

She is requesting a loan to expand her business by buying a greater quantity and variety of basic products to stock in her store and better satisfy her customers. She hopes her business runs smoothly and will generate a higher income to assist her in improving her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To buy a greater quantity and variety of basic products to stock in her store

loans.name: Billy

texts.en: 50-year-old Billy raises hogs for a living. He is married with 3 children. Billy has been in the business of hog raising for 2 years. He earns 4000 PHP per month with this business. Billy works hard to improve his income and provide for his family's needs. He requested a loan to buy additional feed and piglets. He hopes to earn a better income and be able to send all of his children to school.

loans.use: to buy additional feed and piglets

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
Ly is 44 years old and is married with three children, a son and two daughters. Her husband is a driver for hire.

Ly has been running a general store in front of her door for 6 years. She started this business to cover her expenses and to generate income to raise her children. She lives with her family in Ho Chi Minh City.

Ly is requesting a loan to expand her business by buying more household items and many kinds of soft drinks to stock her stall. She hopes that this will enable her to attract more customers and that she will be able to increase the turnover of her business. She hopes that through the loan she will be able to expand her business activities, and have money to reinvest to her business in the future.

loans.use: To buy more household items and many kinds of soft drinks.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is a married woman with six children aged between 12 and 27 years. Her husband works as a farmer and carpenter.

Virginia is involved in an agricultural business. She helps her husband grow rice crops on their land. She also raises pigs to sell. Virginia works hard to support her family and send her children to school. She has applied for a loan to purchase seedlings, fertilizers, piglets, and feeds. She hopes to elevate her family's standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase seedlings, fertilizers, piglets, and feeds.

loans.name: Huyen

texts.en:
Huyen is a 49-year-old married woman. She lives with two daughters and her husband in Ho Chi Minh City. She and her husband earn money by selling newspapers and running a food stall to sell soup to people in their community. They started this business 6 years ago.

Huyen would like a loan to purchase a greater quantity and a better quality of ingredients to make better soup and foods to sell. She hopes this will enable her to better attract additional customers and be able to increase her income and save money for any future difficulties facing her family.

loans.use: To purchase higher quality ingredients to make better food.

loans.name: Phuong

texts.en:
Phuong is 55 years old and is married. She has eight children, five sons and three daughters. She lives with her children and husband in Ho Chi Minh City.

Phuong and her husband earn a living by making traditional lanterns. They have done this for 7 years. To increase her income from this business, she intends to borrow money to purchase materials such as bamboo, papers, and inks to increase her production of lanterns in preparation for the forthcoming Festival of Vietnamese Children.

She hopes her business will run smoothly and will help her to improve her family's living conditions and save money for her childrens' educations.

loans.use: to purchase materials such as bamboo, papers, and inks to increase the production of lanterns for the forthcoming Festival of Vietnamese Children.

loans.name: Nhung

texts.en:
Nhung, 43, is single and lives in Ho Chi Minh City. She earns an income running a cafe at her house. She started this business six years ago. She sells soft drinks, coffee, yogurt, and food to people in her community. 

Nhung is requesting a loan to expand her business by buying a greater variety of foods and beverages to better satisfy her customers. She hopes her business runs smoothly and will generate a higher income to assist her in improving her living conditions.

loans.use: To buy a greater variety of foods and beverages to better satisfy her customers.

loans.name: Mui

texts.en:
Mui, 47, is a married woman with two sons. They live in Ho Chi Minh City. Her husband supports the family through the income he earns from making slipper molds.

Mui has run a general store that occupies the front of her house for 5 years. She sells a small variety of goods. She intends to take a loan to buy a larger variety of different goods, such as foods and beverages, to stock her store and better meet her customers' needs. She hopes her expanded business will help her to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to buy a larger variety of different goods to stock her store.

loans.name: Mai

texts.en:
Mai, 52, lives in a small house in Ho Chi Minh City with her family, including two daughters, one son and her husband. Mai and her husband earn money through their business producing slippers. 

Mai is sometimes unable to provide the volume of slippers required by her customers. Consequently she would like to get a loan to buy a larger stock of material to make slippers and increase her production to meet her customers' needs. She also hopes her business will ensure that her family members, and especially her children, will have a better education and a better future.

loans.use: to buy a larger stock of material to make slippers.

loans.name: Bendu

texts.en: Bendu lives in Airport, is thirty years of age and married.  She has two children aged one and eleven.  Her husband is a social worker and her two children are in school.  For the past eleven years she has been selling soft drinks and cosmetics.  Some problems she is facing includes affording a place to sell (shop).  She likes the buying in her business, her plan is to build a shop for her business, educate her children and build her own house.

loans.use: to purchase soft drinks and cosmetics for her business.

loans.name: Quang

texts.en:
Quang, 44, is married and has two children.  He lives with his family in Ho Chi Minh City.  He and his wife earn a living with a business, selling haircare products.

He is requesting a loan to expand his business by buying a greater quantity and quality of haircare products to better satisfy his customers.

He hopes the business runs smoothly and will generate a higher income to assist him in improving his family's living conditions and sending his children to school.

loans.use: to buy a greater quantity and quality of haircare products.

loans.name: Jose Luis

texts.es:
El señor Jose Luis es casado, tiene 32 años de edad, cursó los 3 años de educación primaria, tiene 2 hijos 1 de los cuales está estudiando, se dedica a la carpintería, a la elaboración de todo tipo de muebles, roperos, camas, estanterías, etc., inició este trabajo como trabajo y hasta ahora lleva 13 años de experiencia.

Solicita un prestamo que le servirá para la compra de madera ya que su negocio tiene demanda y espera producir más, cuenta con el apoyo de su esposa quien se dedica a oficio domésticos. En el futuro espera tener su negocio grandes y con mejores ganancias.
texts.en:
Sr. Jose Luis is married, 32 years old and has had three years of primary school education. He has 2 children, one of whom is in school. He is a carpenter and makes all kinds of furniture, wardrobes, beds, bookcases, etc. He started the business and has had 13 years of experience.

He is applying for a loan that he will use to buy wood since his business has orders and he hopes to produce more. He relies on the support of his wife, who is engaged in  domestic work. In the future he hopes to have a larger business and earn better profits.

loans.use: to buy wood.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary lives in Sinkor, is 48 years old, married, and has seven children between the ages of 14 and 28. She says six of them are out of high school and living on their own, while the smallest one lives at home and attends school. Her husband is a security guard. Mary says at a young age, her parents did not have money to send her to school. 

Since 1990, she has been selling dried and fresh fish in the market. She is a member of the Market Women Associations of Liberia (MWAL). She received a loan from her friends to start her business. She enjoys interacting with her customers. She says she has been a good borrower of BRAC since 2010 and wishes to be a member of Kiva.

She is asking for a loan ($25,000 LD) to buy more dried and fresh fish and to expand her business. Her plan is to build a house for her children.

loans.use: to buy more dried and fresh fish and expand her business

loans.name: Nérida

texts.es:
Nérida tiene 36 años, tiene 3 hijos; de 15, 12 y 8 años. Ella y sus hijos viven en una casa alquilada ubicada en el distrito de Perené – Chanchamayo.

Ella es una madre ejemplar, desde que se separó del padre de sus hijos aprendió a desempeñarse en muchas actividades. Desde ayudante en un restaurante y de vendedora por catálogo. Poco a poco fue formando un negocio propio, y actualmente cuenta con una tienda de abarrotes ubicada en la casa donde vive. “Para tener esa tienda me tuve que prestar dinero de unos familiares, pero felizmente cancelé mis deudas”, comenta. 
En todo este tiempo pudo captar clientela fiel a la que ofrece productos frescos como: carnes, verduras, frutas, golosinas, abarrotes, conservas; y también tiene útiles escolares.  Nérida dice que sus ventas son rentables gracias a la variedad de comestibles que ofrece.
En adelante, ella quisiera adquirir un terreno propio y construir su casa propia, es uno de sus más grandes anhelos.

Éste es su primer préstamo con MFP y se compromete en pagar con responsabilidad las cuotas mensuales. Ella pertenece al banco comunal “Las Independientes - 2012” y se siente emocionada de compartir actividades con mujeres solidarias.
El dinero solicitado lo invertirá en la compra de mercadería necesaria para abastecer su negocio como: arroz, azúcar, aceite, carnes, frutas, verduras, etc.
texts.en:
Nérida is 36 years old and has three children ages 15, 12, and 8.  She and her children live in a rental house located in the district of Perené – Chanchamayo.

She is an exemplary mother, and since she separated from the father of her children, she has learned to carry out many commercial activities.  From restaurant hostess to catalog sales, little by little she has created her own business and currently owns a small grocery store located in the house where she lives.  "To have this shop, I had to borrow money from my friends, but happily, I have been able to repay all my debts," she said.

In this time, she was able to attract loyal customers, to whom she offers fresh products like meats, vegetables, fruits, sweets, groceries, fruit preserves, and also school materials.  Nérida says that her sales are quite good thanks to the variety of consumer goods that she offers.

Going forward, she would like to acquire her own property and construct her own house; this is one of her deepest desires.

This is her first loan with MFP and she promises to pay promptly and responsibly each monthly installment.  She is a member of the community bank “Las Independientes - 2012” and she feels very excited to share in activities with women who have similar interests.  The money she requests will be invested in buying the merchandise needed to stock her business, like rice, sugar, oil, meats, fruits, vegetables, etc.

loans.use: to increase her selection of merchandise.

loans.name: Nu

texts.en:
Nu is 53 years old and married with two children (one son and one daughter). She lives with her husband and children in Ho Chi Minh City. Her husband works as a security guard. Nu earns income to support her family by making and selling sweetened bean porridge for people in her community. 

Nu has run this business for the past twenty-seven years. She would like to take a loan to invest in her current business by buying a greater quantity and better quality of ingredients. She also would like to use a part of her loan to buy a small scooter for transportation. 

She hopes that this loan will help her to better meet the needs of her customers and will attract more customers to her food stall. She hopes that through the loan she will be able to increase her income to more adequately cover family expenses.

loans.use: to buy a greater quantity and better quality of ingredients to make food to sell from her stall

loans.name: Tete

texts.en: Tete lives in Sinkor, is 40 years old, married, and has four children that are in school and live at home. She stopped her education in the 9th grade. Since 1996, she has been selling  rice, palm oil, pepper, vita, and other items in the market. She does not have enough income to meet customer needs. She is requesting a loan to purchase more rice, palm oil, pepper, vita, and other items to expand her business. She started this business with a small loan that she received from her sister, and learned this trade from her friends. She enjoys interacting with her customers, and having money in her home makes her proud. Her wish is to improve her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase more rice, palm oil, pepper, vita, and other items to expand her business

loans.name: Frances

texts.en:
Frances is 38 years old and married with four children between the ages of 10 to 18. All of her children live at home and are in school, and her husband is a contractor.

For 20 years now, Frances has been selling used clothes and rice bread (traditional bread made of banana and rice dust). She says her obligation can’t allow her to meet customers’ needs, so she is requesting a loan of 20,000 Liberia dollars (LRD) to purchase used clothes, rice, and bananas to increase her sales. Her plan is to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase used clothes, rice, and bananas to increase her sales.

loans.name: Precious

texts.en:
Precious lives in Sinkor. She is 42 years old and single with five children between the ages of 10 and 20, all of whom are in school and live at home.

Precious is a university student. Since 1989 she has been involved in a local business, making soap and frying plantains. Sometimes her customers purchase on credit and don’t pay. She learned this way of selling from her friend, who she calls her motivator.

Precious likes her business because it makes her self sufficient. She is requesting a loan to purchase caustic, wood, oil, charcoal, plastic, and plantains for her business. Her plans is to become a international businesswoman.

loans.use: to purchase caustic, wood, oil, charcoal, plastic, and plantains for her business.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 23 years old and lives in Sinkor with a 2-year-old child who stays at home. She stopped her education in the 10th grade.

For the last 5 years, Mary has been selling slippers in her community. She started this business with a loan from her father-in-law. She is requesting a loan to purchase more slippers for her business. She likes the way her customers buy from her. In the near future, she want to travel and become a international businesswoman.

loans.use: to purchase more slippers for her business.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a mother of three children aged between nine and four years. She has been in the farming business for twelve years and has two farmhands. She runs a milk bar business at the local market in addition to her farming.  Her farm currently produces maize, milk, and nappier grass for the local market.
 
Jane has made a loan request of 25,000 KES from Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to buy a dairy cow. She says that the acquisition of a dairy cow will provide milk for family consumption as well as help her earn more income to meet her family's other needs. She aspires to run a farm of high-quality dairy cows.

Jane says pests and diseases are the major challenges with her farming.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Fanny Bienvenida

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal Nuevos Horizontes se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Jipijapa, cantón conocido con el nombre de la sultana del café por los extensos cultivos de café el cual tiene un sabor incomparable, por su gastronomía y por la calidez de su gente. 

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Fanny, tiene 52 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen cinco hijos todos mayores de edad,  dos de sus hijos aun viven en su casa y ya son profesionales. Su esposo es mecánico automotriz.

Ella con la intención de ganar algo por su cuenta y con esto sentirse útil y no tener que depender de nadie para sus gastos se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo y repuestos para automóviles, para lo cual  tiene un local en su casa. Ella aprovecha que muchas personas llegan al taller de su esposo y si necesitan algún repuesto ella les vende, en cuanto a la ropa también vende por las noches ya que visita a sus clientes, trabaja todos los días desde las 8 h00 hasta las 19h00 cuando sale a recorrer. Su mercadería  la va a comprar a  Guayaquil cada vez que necesita. Lleva 14  años con este negocio y le va muy bien.

Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar más mercadería como: pantalones, blusas, camisetas y ciertos repuestos de vehículos que necesita de urgencia. Lleva 14 años en el Banco Comunal  y le gusta porque con el primer crédito empezó su negocio. 

Sus sueños son continuar con su negocio y salir adelante.
texts.en:
The Nuevos Horizontes communal bank meets every two weeks in Jipijapa Canton, a canton known as La Sultana del Café because of its extensive fields of incomparably flavored coffee, for its cuisine, and for the warmth of its people.

Here we met Fanny, 52.  She is married and has five adult children from this relationship, two of whom still live at home and are professionals.  Her husband is an auto mechanic.

With the goal of earning something on her own and thus feeling useful and not having to depend on anyone for her expenses, she sells all types of clothing and auto parts, for which she has a place in her house.  She makes the most of many people coming to her husband's shop, and if they need some part she sells it to them.  With regard to the clothing, she also sells at night because she visits her customers.

She works every day from 8 a.m. until 7 p.m. when she goes out to sell.  She goes to Guayaquil to buy her merchandise every time she needs some.  She has had this business for 14 years and it is going very well for her.

She is going to use this loan to buy more merchandise such as pants, blouses, t-shirts, and certain vehicle parts that she needs urgently.  She has been in the communal bank for 14 years and she likes it because she started her business with her first loan.

Her dreams are to continue with her business and to get ahead.

loans.use: to buy pants, blouses, t-shirts, and car parts.

loans.name: Mary July

texts.es:
Mary   es una mujer que tiene 21 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente, con un  hijos a su cargo,  vive  en casa propia con su cónyuge. Se menciona que  La calidad de vida en la comunidad es de subsistencia, la mayoría de moradores  son trabajadores independientes  que se dedican al comercio y crianza de animales menores y algunos de ellos adicionalmente dedicados a la agricultura. Mary  vive en  el caserío Los Bances del distrito de Túcume y departamento de  Lambayeque, así mismo cuenta solamente con el servicio  básico de energía eléctrica, y el consumo de agua lo hacen a través de un pozo artezanal;  Así mismo todas las familias que radican ahí viven bajo estas condiciones.
 La actividad comercial a la que se dedica Mary es la venta de chicha de jora y piqueos, esto  lo hace en su domicilio, también se dedica a la crianza/venta de ganado porcinos  y aves de corral, la crianza de estos animales la realiza en corrales externos a  su domicilio; cabe destacar que en esta actividad Mary cuenta con 2 años de experiencia, lo que le ha permitido mantener su clientela ya establecida en este negocio; ella vende sus animales a los comerciantes mayoristas de la zona; Así mismo su cónyuge también esta dedicado al transporte de pasajeros, en  donde   le permite tener otro ingresos adicionales.
Actualmente Mary se ha propuesto ampliar su inventario en lo referente a la venta de piqueos, chicha de jora y a la crianza y venta de animales, esto debido a que es una actividad muy rentable en la zona; es por estas circunstancias  que esta solicitando un nuevo préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa por un monto de S/.1000 nuevos soles el cual estará destinado a la inversión de compra de ollas, cucharones, coladores y alimentos balanceados, y arreglos de corrales para sus animales; lo cual en el tiempo le va permitir ir mejorando su nivel de VIDA.
texts.en:
Mary is a 21 year old woman in a civil marriage with one child in her care.  She lives in her own house together with her spouse.  It is noted that in the community where she lives, the community's quality of life is subsistence level, the majority are day laborers and some are independent business people who practice trade and raise domestic animals and some also involve themselves in agriculture. Mary lives in the neighborhood of Los Bances of the district of Túcume and department of Lambayeque, where there is only basic electrical service and the community water comes from an artesian well; here all the families around live under these same conditions.

The commercial activity practiced by Mary is the sales of traditional corn liquor (chicha de jora) and snacks, which she does from her home.  She is also involved in the growth and sales of pigs and poultry, and the raising of these animals happens in outdoor corrals on her land; it's worth emphasizing that Mary has 2 years of experience, which has allowed her to hold a steady customer base already established with her business. She sells her animals to the largest merchants in her area.  Her spouse also works in passenger transport, which allows them to have another source of income.

Currently, Mary has proposed expanding her inventory in regards to her snacks, corn liquor, and the growth and sales of animals, all because it is a very lucrative business in her area. It is for this reason that she is asking for a new loan from Edpyme Alternativa in the amount of S/.1000 Soles, which will be designated for investment in buying pots, serving spoons, colanders, and nutritionally balanced feed and corral repairs for her animals, which will, in time, allow her to improve her quality of life.

loans.use: to buy materials for her business and to buy feed for animals.

loans.name: Benitta D.

texts.en: Benitta D. is 32 years old and lives in Sinkor. She is married and her husband is a  mechanic. They have three children between  9 months  and 15 years old.  Two are in school and  all of them live at home.  For the past 12   years Benitta D.has been operating a cook shop (restaurant) in her community.  She has a lot of customer sand she makes a lot of profit. She is requesting a loan to purchase more rice, pepper, oil, coal and others items for her business. Benitta D. plans to build a house and educate her children.

loans.use: to purchase more rice, pepper, oil, coal and others items for her business

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris is a farmer in the Nkubu area of Central Kenya and is married with six children, four of whom are still in school.
